DIALOGUE BEFORE: Player Default: Yeah, if our places were reversed, I'd probably want the same thing.
RESPONSE TEXT: Then I trust you will honor my wish.
DIALOGUE AFTER: Sierra: You can't kill him! He's a great man! He invented Nuka-Cola, the best thing in the world!

DIALOGUE BEFORE: Player Default: There's got to be a better solution than killing you.
RESPONSE TEXT: That's easy for you to say, standing there on your own two legs, able to go where you wish and do what you want.
DIALOGUE AFTER: Sierra: You can't kill him! He's a great man! He invented Nuka-Cola, the best thing in the world!

DIALOGUE BEFORE: Player Default: Come on, you're a disembodied head trapped in a vault. You've got so much to live for!
RESPONSE TEXT: Despite your obvious sarcasm, you clearly recognize my situation for the living hell that it is.
DIALOGUE AFTER: Sierra: You can't kill him! He's a great man! He invented Nuka-Cola, the best thing in the world!

DIALOGUE BEFORE: Player Default: Are you really sure that you want to die?
RESPONSE TEXT: I've had plenty of time to think about it.
DIALOGUE AFTER: Sierra: You can't kill him! He's a great man! He invented Nuka-Cola, the best thing in the world!

DIALOGUE BEFORE: Player Default: I'm not shutting off the power. With Sierra to keep you company, I think you'll both be happier.
RESPONSE TEXT: What?! Will you not respect the wishes of a man who has suffered the way I have? Please, I beg you to reconsider!

DIALOGUE BEFORE: Player Default: I'll do it. I'll shut off the power.
RESPONSE TEXT: Thank you.
Now please do get on with it. I'm ready. I've been ready for a long, long time.

DIALOGUE BEFORE: Player Default: I haven't decided yet.
RESPONSE TEXT: I see. I can only hope your sense of compassion compels you to do the right thing. I've been a prisoner long enough.

DIALOGUE BEFORE: Player Default: What about Sierra's offer to keep you company? Wouldn't that help?
RESPONSE TEXT: I admit I'm flattered by her admiration, but I'm so tired, in ways that words could not explain.
I've lived far too long already, and I'm prepared to move on.
I await your decision.
DIALOGUE AFTER: Player Default: I'm not shutting off the power. With Sierra to keep you company, I think you'll both be happier.

DIALOGUE BEFORE: Sierra: You can't kill him! He's a great man! He invented Nuka-Cola, the best thing in the world!
RESPONSE TEXT: Young lady, you don't know what a torment it is, being trapped here alone and staring at the same wall, decade after decade.
Now please shut up while I talk to your more rational friend here
DIALOGUE AFTER: BradbertonsHead: I realize that what I'm asking isn't easy, but there's something in it for you.

DIALOGUE BEFORE: BradbertonsHead: Now please shut up while I talk to your more rational friend here
RESPONSE TEXT: I realize that what I'm asking isn't easy, but there's something in it for you.
When the power is cut, the door to the prototype storage room will open automatically. Take anything you want. I don't care anymore.
Just... please... set me free at last. I can't bear this loneliness any longer.
DIALOGUE AFTER: Sierra: Wait, wait, wait! I have an idea!

DIALOGUE BEFORE: Sierra: It's one of my most treasured possessions, but... well... I'm willing to let you have it.
RESPONSE TEXT: A Nuka-Cola jumpsuit? Hah! That's a paltry prize compared to what I'm offering.
The choice is yours, but I beg you to honor my wishes. There is noone else who can help me.

DIALOGUE BEFORE: Sierra: That's John-Caleb Bradberton! Or at least, it's his head. Wow!
RESPONSE TEXT: Who... who are you? I haven't seen a real human face in so long. I had given up all hope.
DIALOGUE AFTER: Sierra: Oh my God! It's alive! He's alive!
SCRIPT NOTES: Surprised, seeing humans for the first time in decades / Surprised

DIALOGUE BEFORE: DLC04NPCMJohnCalebBradberton: You there, with the Pip-Boy. What are you doing here?
RESPONSE TEXT: You there, with the Pip-Boy. What are you doing here?
DIALOGUE AFTER: Player Default: We solved your Hidden Cappy contest.

DIALOGUE BEFORE: Player Default: We solved your Hidden Cappy contest.
RESPONSE TEXT: The Hidden Cappy contest... it all seems so long ago. Another lifetime.
That was before I became this monster. Before I was trapped here for centuries to suffer in solitude.
DIALOGUE AFTER: BradbertonsHead: This was General Braxton's plan all along. Damn the man!

DIALOGUE BEFORE: Player Default: This has to be a joke.
RESPONSE TEXT: You trespass in my private vault in my office in my amusement park, and you have the gall to treat me like some joke?
Oh, what's the use. Look at me. Look at me! I'm a monster, trapped in a prison of my own making.
DIALOGUE AFTER: BradbertonsHead: This was General Braxton's plan all along. Damn the man!

DIALOGUE BEFORE: Player Default: We used the contest code to get in. What the hell happened to you?
RESPONSE TEXT: I made a devil's bargain, though I didn't know it at the time.
DIALOGUE AFTER: BradbertonsHead: This was General Braxton's plan all along. Damn the man!

DIALOGUE BEFORE: Player Default: That was before I became this monster. Before I was trapped here for centuries to suffer in solitude.
RESPONSE TEXT: This was General Braxton's plan all along. Damn the man!
He called it Project Cobalt. In exchange for my weapon design, he would give me access to life-extending technology.
I'm such a fool for taking him at his word. He never told me that this would be the price!
DIALOGUE AFTER: Player Default: I can't imagine what you must have gone through. I'm truly sorry, Mister Bradberton.

DIALOGUE BEFORE: Player Default: When something sounds too good to be true, it usually is.
RESPONSE TEXT: You don't think I know that? You don't think I've contemplated my folly for decades on end?
I do not need some interloper to remind me of my greatest tragedy!
DIALOGUE AFTER: Sierra: A... a weapon? I don't believe it. Why would the genius who brought so much joy to the world want to make something destructive?

DIALOGUE BEFORE: Player Default: Smart enough to invent Nuka-Cola, but you still fell for that?
RESPONSE TEXT: Yes, make your jokes, but I've still accomplished ten times more in a single lifetime than anyone I've met, including you!
As long as one person in this world still enjoys Nuka-Cola, my legacy remains intact, no matter what I've been reduced to!
DIALOGUE AFTER: Sierra: A... a weapon? I don't believe it. Why would the genius who brought so much joy to the world want to make something destructive?

DIALOGUE BEFORE: Player Default: Who was General Braxton?
RESPONSE TEXT: He was one of the top men in the Army Research Laboratory's Weapons and Materials division.
He'd taken a keen interest in my quantum mechanics research, and offered me a trade.
In exchange for my assistance on a top-secret weapons project, he gave me access to an experimental process tthat would artificially extend my life.
Like a fool, I leapt before I looked. I've certainly paid the price for my short-sightedness.
DIALOGUE AFTER: Sierra: A... a weapon? I don't believe it. Why would the genius who brought so much joy to the world want to make something destructive?

DIALOGUE BEFORE: Sierra: A... a weapon? I don't believe it. Why would the genius who brought so much joy to the world want to make something destructive?
RESPONSE TEXT: Genius is restless, madam! It must expand, seek new challenges, and explore new frontiers. So yes, a weapon.
It was going to be a quantum-enhanced variant of the standard portable tactical warhead.
In fact, the prototypes are stored in this very chamber. You can have them, on one condition.
I want you to shut off the power to this machine that's keeping me alive. I want to die.
DIALOGUE AFTER: Sierra: What?! No!

RESPONSE TEXT: I realize my appearance is disturbing, but do try to focus.
SCRIPT NOTES: Impatient, the player has stopped responding

RESPONSE TEXT: It seems both of us have become frozen.
SCRIPT NOTES: Impatient, the player has stopped responding

RESPONSE TEXT: So. Have you made up your mind?
DIALOGUE AFTER: Player Default: I'm not shutting off the power. With Sierra to keep you company, I think you'll both be happier.

RESPONSE TEXT: In regards to Nuka-Cola Clear production, I think it's obvious that we need to take a step back and examine the facts.
SCRIPT NOTES: as if dictating for records purposes / Confident

RESPONSE TEXT: Project Cobalt dropped Quantum in our laps, so I think it's best we leverage its potential popularity before someone else beats us to market.
SCRIPT NOTES: as if dictating for records purposes / Concerned

RESPONSE TEXT: Additionally, installing the equipment to produce both flavors would cost us a pretty penny and I'd rather use the funds to promote Quantum.
SCRIPT NOTES: as if dictating for records purposes / Confident

RESPONSE TEXT: We also have our Lemon-Lime flavor debuting soon, and need to work out how to market two clear-colored flavors simultaneously.
SCRIPT NOTES: as if dictating for records purposes / Concerned

RESPONSE TEXT: With all these factors taken into account, I have no choice but to hold off Nuka-Cola Clear production for at least the next two fiscal years.
SCRIPT NOTES: as if dictating for records purposes / Confident

DIALOGUE BEFORE: Player Default: You either sign off on Project Cobalt, or I can walk right out that door.
RESPONSE TEXT: This isn't like deciding what color bottle to pick for our next flavor, General.
You're asking me to take my laboratories and my Beverageers, and basically turn them over to your team.
I need assurances that my people and my facilities are going to be treated with the respect that they deserve.
DIALOGUE AFTER: Player Default: You and I both know that's a load of horse shit.

DIALOGUE BEFORE: Player Default: I already told you you'd be well compensated. Now, cut the crap and tell me what you're really after.
RESPONSE TEXT: Fine. I want in on the military's LEAP-X Program.
DIALOGUE AFTER: Player Default: What? How the hell did you know about that?
SCRIPT NOTES: Leap-Ex say it like a word / Confident

DIALOGUE BEFORE: Player Default: What? How the hell did you know about that?
RESPONSE TEXT: Let's just say you're not the only one in this room that can throw his weight around in Washington, General.
I've been following the program ever since its inception, and I have to say that I'm impressed.
The ability to keep a human in a state of veritable immortality using a machine? Now that's something that I didn't expect from the military.
Look. You want me to agree to this proposal, then get me on the LEAP-X list, and I'll sign whatever you want.
DIALOGUE AFTER: Player Default: I always knew you were a greedy son-of-a-bitch, John. But the last thing I expected to hear is that you were afraid of death.

DIALOGUE BEFORE: Player Default: It isn't as easy as throwing a switch and suddenly you can live forever.
RESPONSE TEXT: Stop trying to talk me out of it.
We both know the enemy is developing chemical and biological weapons and that my Beverageers are the top organic chemists in the world.
Our countries are in a race where no one comes in second, General.
So you need to ask yourself: can you really afford to stand here and say "no."
DIALOGUE AFTER: Player Default: You had this all figured out before I even arrived, didn't you?

RESPONSE TEXT: I won't deny that it's nice to have some company again.
I commend your diligence. It can't have been easy to find your way in here.
I'm pleased to know that even now, the legacy of my work is still appreciated. Sierra has made that very clear to me.
Help yourself to anything that you think is useful. None of it means much to me anymore.
You can't know how wonderful a real conversation can be until you've gone without one for a few hundred years.
SCRIPT NOTES: Grateful, relieved, a weight has been lifted

RESPONSE TEXT: Finally... free at last...
DIALOGUE AFTER: Sierra: No! Mister Bradberton... I'm sorry.
